comments.commentBody:
As a parent to a toddler conceived with the help of a known donor, I echo the sentiments of many of the previous commenters that it is very possible to explain situations that are complicated for adults to children - and most of the time the kids don't find it complicated. My son knows his "Honey" and knows that he started growing inside Mama with Honey's help.

I do want to point out that most (but certainly not all) donor-created families would object to the use of the term "daddy" or "father" to describe the role of the sperm donor. This seems to me akin to describing the birth parents of an adoptive child as the child's mother and father, without clarification of "biological father" or "birth mother". Our donor self-describes his role to people in his life as that of a "donor-daddy". We refer to him to our friends as our donor or as our son's Honey, and we gently correct folks who ask "who the father is" by responding that "we're the only parents; our donor is a friend of ours."
My, My, an attractive woman like that doing such violence to tiny worms.

Unfortunately I do have an adult friend, born in the early 1960s, who found her biological mother about 20 years ago, and money cane between them. The biological mother pressed my friend for a large loan (which she and her husband decided to provide, even though their finances are shaky). They are no longer in touch.
My friend found out why she was placed for adoption (single mom, married boyfriend who never left his wife although he said he would) and what her biological family is like, and that was enough.
I too object to anyone seeking out minor children for any kind of contact without going through the child's parents first. That applies anything legal or emotionally loaded.

Sure, the cranky old man in me wants to tell these kids to get off my lawn, but what have they shown us? Mostly, that cyber-security is terrible, that our supposedly safe information is anything but, and that large corporations and government agencies are not telling the truth when they say they've secured our data. I'd say those revelations far outweigh the attitude they give off.

Sure, go ahead and limit the effectiveness of one of the few companies that are American and successful.
Just how much money was slipped to some of the FTC bureaucrats by some of Google's competitors ?

FairSearch.org does not play fair. For example it accuses Google of "manipulation of search results to favor Google’s products".
Now, you type into Google a product,. I just typed in Nikon D3100.
I looked at all the results on the first two pages. No Google page appears in the results (most of them are nikonusa webpages). Then I switched to Google shopping. There appears one "Google product" : Google checkout. However, it is unchecked, so it is up to the user to opt in.
So where is that manipulation ???

The "Winklevi" as referred to in "The Social Network" are completely nuts. For doing very little work and shouldering no risk, they've been showered with tens of millions of dollars, yet they continue this insane quest for nine years. Move on, guys.
The FTC geniuses might remember that Google is free, and fast.  There's no law that says you have to use it.
This I believe is their monetization round. Also, an office in Bangalore/Hyderabad is warranted. Facebook does it.
Sounds like a shakedown of Facebook to me. What a waste of the Court's time. They should be happy with what they got.

You are better off with 5 true friends and 100 so called enemies than no friends and no enemies.

My mom said "the worst thing you can do to an enemy is ignore him" and LulzSec is smart enough to do just that......
"Winklevoss" is distinctive enough that it would make a good verb, as in : "My startup is really taking off, but there's a guy trying to winklevoss me."

What a nice piece of theater, making the public think this Regime is going to "get tough" with Google.

The Bamster is a big buddy of Google, so don't expect anything of consequence to happen here.

These kids should stick to their video games.

Trust me, there's very little to "laugh" about when there's an actual policeman across an actual table from you.
Greedy and lazy are good words to describe these two leeches
I'm deeply ashamed of misguided hacking groups like LulzSec and Anonymous. Sick children...

Looks like Ringleadr.com beat them to the punch... interesting to see how this all flushes out.

http://techcrunch.com/2011/06/23/ringleadr-raises-500k-launches-service-...
While they're at it, They might ask The Google to pay taxes.

RAB illustrates the danger of teaching a giggling talentless (DDoS? Really?) child a word like "fascist" before he has the maturity to grasp its meaning.

I hope that he and his cohorts are old enough to be tried as adults so they can each share a cell with some iron-pumping lifer who really needs something to relieve his boredom and pent up frustrations. You won't subject him to DoS, and he'll define the S.

Too bad we won't see videos of that posted on youtube. Now that's something I'd giggle over. It also would cause a lot of Lulzers to consider other forms of amusement.

worthless story, pretending there is "good hacking".  you people are so twisted, you have no idea what a good person is anymore.  Is it yours? No?  Then keep your hands off.  I don't care if I'm talking to the govt, hackers, or some joe on the street.  Also, since when is being a narc a great thing?  This society has gone down the toilet.  The stupid masses cheer as it happens, not recognizing their impending doom.

Larry said: "It's not always a matter of gullibility or stupidity; but a lack of knowledge, and we all can't be knowledgeable about everything."

You don't need knowledge of how to fix a computer any more than you need knowledge of how to fix a car. You just need sufficient common sense to know when to ask for help. If you were driving happily down the road and a strange man flagged you down while yelling "Your brakes are failing, you need to give me your credit card right now so I can fix them" what would you do? Even if the guy was driving a tow truck, a reasonable person would have warning bells going off in their heads about the sheer insanity of the request, and simply seek advice from a trusted professional.

Whether you agree with someone's politics, etc., or not, if you do this kind of thing, especially with personal information, you should be trcked down, prosecuted to the fullest extent of the criminal law, and sued out of your socks for invasion of privacy.

I have read several things about the government's and other entities' new proposed Secure Identities program. Some bloggers appear to think or argue that it would give the government more access to our private communications and data, but it seems to me, without a technical background--none of my hacker friends will teach me to hack--that it would tighten up security and not give the government any more access than it, not to mention criminals, have now. Would someone knowledgeable please comment?

I want the terrorists and child porn exploiters caught, but I sometimes can only post certain factual information of significant public importance anonymously because identifying myself would tend to identify others with whom I have or have had privileged and confidential information, and really don't want the government allowed to use all the technology appropriate to rescue a kidnap victim, prevent murder or child abuse, or counter terrorism used against everybody who falls afoul of every little law on the books. I also think that personal privacy is one of the essentials of liberty and freedom of expression that rises to 9th Amendment unenumerated Constitutional significance, and you should not lose that by taking a stand on a controversial issue much less by being a crime victim or so-called "involuntary public figure."
"Jester" sounds like a front for the US Govt.
Lulz shows how fragile internet security is and should serve as a wake up call for government agencies. Imagine the damage more malicious groups could inflict.

I've been reporting on this at infosecisland.com and am waiting for it to be published there. No such luck ... they've merely changed their name to somebody else I suppose to ditch the press. They're busy distributing the source code for the zeus trojan now so that the followers-on can write their own variants.

Lulzboat's twitter is now lulzb0at (how clever), they're now running also a school4lulz, and of course antisec, anonops and lolhackers are still going strong. So all that's going on here is that the roaches are scattering ...

In the meantime, updates can be read here:

http://www.wilderssecurity.com/showthread.php?p=1894444#post1894444
http://www.dslreports.com/forum/r26020761-Lulzboat-runs-aground-they-re-...
https://www.infosecisland.com/ (as soon as the update is published)

Over time, these guys themselves will become the "middle-aged self-titled failures" they are now mocking, and I'm *sure* they will take it in good part when someone in future decides to rock their little world in the name of  the "raw, uninterrupted, chaotic thrill of entertainment and anarchy".  Maybe then they'll understand fully what losers they've been all along.
